journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: A study of the contact stress analysis of cylindrical gears using the hybrid finite element method

article-meta.aff: 1Advanced Institute of Manufacturing with High-tech Innovations, National Chung Cheng University, Min-Hsiung, Taiwan, ROC
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Chung Cheng University, Min-Hsiung, Taiwan, ROC
3Hanbell Precise Machinery Co., Ltd, Taichung City, Taiwan, ROC

author-notes.corresp: Zhang-Hua Fong, Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Chung Cheng University, No. 168, University Road, Min-Hsiung, Chia-yi County 62102, Taiwan, ROC. Email: imezhf@hotmail.com

abstract.p: In this study, the hybrid finite element method combined with the tooth contact analysis was applied to solve the static contact stress problem of meshing a cylindrical gear set. The hybrid finite element method has two special features. First, the dimension of the stiffness matrix was reduced to a small condensed compliance matrix with degrees of freedom in the possible contact region. The contact force was iteratively solved based on the condensed compliance matrix by the normal gap distance at the contact point. Second, the contact force at the meshing positions was solved using the same condensed compliance matrix with a different normal gap distance calculated by the tooth contact analysis. Using the examples in this study, the contact stress of the meshing gears was calculated and compared to the data obtained by ANSYS in order to validate the proposed hybrid finite element method. The hybrid finite element method with tooth contact analysis proposed in this study can be used to determine the amount of tooth surface modification.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Gears are widely used in mechanical power transmission devices. The strength of these gears is often roughly estimated using the AGMA, ISO, or DIN gear rating standards and further verified by commercially available finite element method (FEM) analysis packages such as ANSYS, Nastran, etc. However, the FEM analysis is expensive and time consuming when the contact stresses in multiple meshing positions are required. Therefore, an efficient FEM algorithm is required to calculate the stresses being developed in meshing gears for many meshing positions, in order to improve the accuracy of the power rating of gear transmissions.

Litvin1 and Litvin and Fuentes2 proposed the tooth contact analysis (TCA) to obtain the contact pattern of the conjugate tooth profile in terms of the mesh rotation angle. In 1998, Wang et al.3 compared the stress calculations obtained by the FEM and ISO gear standards for helical gears. In 1999, Yang and Wang4 presented the loaded TCA for spur gears by FEM to accurately calculate the deformation of the gears. Lee5 proposed an analysis of the dynamic contact of spur gears using the FEM and multi-body system dynamics method in 2001. His result was quite similar to the real gear contact. In 2002, Lackner and Mang6 presented their automatic mesh generation and mesh refinement procedures for FEM. In 2004, Brauer7 used FEM to study the conical involute gears and developed a parametric design. In 1976, Fredriksson8 presented the super element (SE) to eliminate the freedom of the non-linear problems that are not involved. Chen9 and Li10 proposed the hybrid FEM (HFEM) to solve the elastic contact problems. With this method, the stiffness matrix is transformed into a condensed compliance matrix of the contact force in the contact area. The contact force is iteratively solved by the continuity conditions of the contact area and the condensed compliance matrix. Through HFEM, the whole tooth surface contact problem can be simplified to a local contact problem. In 2001, Kousaku and Naoyuki11 applied FEM in their study of the profile crowning effect on tooth contact stress. In 2009, Takayuki12 defined the load distribution along the contact line and calculated the transmission errors under unloaded and loaded tooth contact conditions. In 2009, Wu and Tsai13 solved the non-Hertz contact problems for optimizing gear tooth modification. In 2010, Zhang et al.14 researched the double circular arc tooth gears. They calculated the standard tooth profile and used a software package to carry out a finite element analysis. The results confirmed that edge modification could decrease the edge contact and reduce contact stress. This edge modification has the same effect on other cylindrical gears.

In this study, we combined the HFEM and TCA to further reduce the computing time for calculating the tooth contact. The global stiffness matrix is calculated as usual by FEM. Then, based on the result of the TCA, the condensed compliance matrix is built with only the degree of freedom (DOF) of the possible contact region and the other DOF is eliminated by a technique similar to the SE. The contact force and the multiple rotational contact positions are both defined by the TCA result. Finally, the solved contact forces of the multiple contact positions are substituted back to the stiffness matrix to solve the stresses of the original FEM model. In the case of tooth profile modification, the compliance of the contact region is almost the same, but the normal gap distance depends largely on the profile modification. To study the profile modification, we must take into consideration the additional normal gap displacement as a result of the profile modification, without recalculating the compliance matrix. The proposed HFEM with TCA in this study can be used to determine the amount of tooth surface modification required.

sec.title: Mathematical model of the gears
sec.p:
The development of involute gears has been described in detail in many studies.1,2 Therefore, in this study, we will only discuss the two-dimensional (2-D) spatial relationship between rack and gear. As shown in Figure 1, the rack translates along the centerline, while the pitch circle rotates around point O1. Assuming that the coordinate systems S0(O0,x0,y0) and S1(O1,x1,y1) are rigidly attached to the rack-cutter and the gear, respectively, the coordinate system Sf(Of,xf,yf) is a fixed coordinate system, the rack profile Î£0=p{xa(ua),ya(ua)}, {nxb,nyb} the unit normal vector of Î£1, and the gear profile Î£1={xb,yb}. The equations of the locus of Î£0 in the coordinate system S1 and the equation of the meshing can be expressed as {xb,yb} and fa in equation (1), respectively (1){xb=cosÎ¸1(xa-r1Î¸1)+sinÎ¸1(r1+ya)yb=cosÎ¸1(r1+ya)+sinÎ¸1(-xa+r1Î¸1)fa(ua,Î¸1)=cosÎ¸1(nyb(-xa+r1Î¸1)+nxbya)âââââââââââââââ-sinÎ¸1(nxb(xa-r1Î¸1)+nybya)=0 Figure 1.
The coordinate relationship between rack-cutter and gear.

Similarly, the other meshing gear can be calculated using the conjugate theory,1,2 and Figure 2 shows the model of a pair of meshing gears. Figure 2.
The gear pair model.

sec.title: The HFEM
sec.p: The HFEM used in this study refers primarily to the one developed by Chen9 and Li10 and includes several modifications such as the gap distance calculation and the contacting forces with non-aligned contact nodes, as will be explained later. Normally, FEM requires adding a contact element between the possible contact nodes to guarantee the deformation compatibility between the mating teeth. However, the contacting node on the meshing surface may not align in the line of action, and the deformed contact nodes might penetrate the surface of the mating element. Therefore, the contact element might need to be rearranged in a different mesh rotation position since there is relative amount of sliding between the surfaces of the mating teeth. A wrong contact element connection between the mating teeth could result in a possible source of error in the deformation compatibility. Even if the contact element is defined correctly, the deformation compatibility is solved iteratively by adding the load gradually and testing the penetration condition in order to find out which contact element is active and which is not. During the gradual loading, the stiffness matrix with the total DOFs is used to solve the node deformation. This deformation is then used to check the compatibility between the contact surfaces. The result is a low level of efficiency because the whole stiffness matrix has to be modified for every iterative procedure.

The static FEM is divided into two methodologies: the stiffness and the force. In the former, the nodal displacement is considered unknown and the stiffness matrix is used to solve the force. The latter method, also known as the flexibility method, considers the nodal force unknown and uses the compliance matrix to solve the displacement. Since most boundary conditions are in the form of fixed displacements, most FEM software packages adopt the displacement method.

The HFEM is somewhere between the stiffness and flexibility methods. It uses the displacement method to build the whole stiffness method and then uses the SE concept to reduce the whole stiffness matrix to the DOF of the contact region. This condensed stiffness matrix is used to build the compliance matrix. The contact force between the tooth surfaces is solved using the flexibility method. The contact force is a force pair that acts on the mating nodes and in the opposite direction. However, the mating contacts might not be properly aligned to each other in every mesh position. Therefore, a TCA is required to estimate the contacting nodes and rearrange the nodal force to the mating surface by the inversed shape function. During the contact-solving process, only the compliance matrix with a DOF in the contact region is required. The size of the compliance matrix is substantially reduced compared to the whole stiffness matrix, allowing the contact state to be solved in a more efficient manner. The proposed HFEM combines the stiffness and flexibility methods with the boundary condition defined by the TCA.

sec.title: Basic assumptions
sec.p:
Assume that two objects, â1 and â2, are in contact at contact point j. The normal vector of contact point j of object â1 is nj. The tangent vector tj is perpendicular to the normal vector nj, and hence, the local coordinate system (nj,tj) is defined as shown in Figure 3. The corresponding contact force along the normal vector nj is Uij. The frictional contact force along the tangent vector tj is Vij(i=1,2;j=1,2,â¦,p; where p is the contact force pair). The normal displacement is uij, tangent displacement vij, and normal gap Énj. The system stiffness equation is represented as equation (2) (2)[K100K2]{u1u1}={P1P2}+{R1R2}{R1}={U11V11U12V12â¦U1pV1p}T{R2}={U21V21U22V22â¦U2pV2p}T} where [Ki] is the entire stiffness matrix (i=1,2, same as below) of âi, {Pi} the entire external load vector of âi, {Ri} the contact force vector of âi, {ui} the nodal displacement vector of âi, Uij the contact force along the normal vector nj of âi, and Vij the frictional contact force along the tangent vector tj of âi. Figure 3.
Local coordinate system for the contact bodies.

sec.title: Deformation compatibility and contact status decision condition
sec.p: Considering the frictionless contact condition, the continuity contact condition of the original gap can be expressed as equations (3) and (4). For the contact status, the additional deformation compatibility equations are (3)U1j+U2j=0V1j=V2j=0u1j=u2j+Énj}
For a separate status, the additional non-contact equations are (4)U1j=U2j=V1j=V2j=0

In equation (2), the [K1], [K2], {P1}, and {P2} are given and {u1}, {u2}, {R1}, and {R2} are unknown. The number of unknown parameters is greater than the number of equations, thus the system equations are indefinite. If there are p contact pairs, then there will be 4p supplementary equations, as defined in equations (3) and (4), and then, equation (2) is transferred to the compliance system equations with 4p unknown contact forces.

Before solving the compliance system equations, we must define the contact status at the possible contact pairs to reduce the number of iterations. The possible contact pair at each rotational mesh position can be determined by TCA. However, the contact pair might not contact at the FEM mesh nodal points exactly. Therefore, the normal gap at the contact pair should be modified to the nearby FEM nodal points on the mating tooth profile. Then, {u1}, {u2}, {R1}, and {R2} can be solved by applying the contact compatibility condition. According to the solved contact forces and deformations of each iteration step, the status of the contact pairs should be redefined according to the contact decision condition. The iteration process will be terminated when there is no penetration on the deformed mating tooth surface (u1j-u2j<0) or a negative contact force pair U1j<0. Table 1 presents the contact decision condition of the contact pair. Table 1.
Contact decision condition.
Initial status Decision condition
Separate U1jâ=â0 Keep separate status
u1jâââu2jâ<â0 Change status to contact
Contact U1jâ>â0 Keep contact status
U1jâ<â0 Change status to separate

sec.title: Relative separation and continuity equations of contact pairs
sec.p:
In equation (6), symbol {s*} denotes the normal separation after loading. The displacement vectors {u2*} of Î£2 and {u1*} of Î£1 denote the deformation after loading in the normal direction of the contact pair. The initial normal gap distance is {É0*}, which indicates the initial gap ({É0*}â>â0) or penetration ({É0*}â<â0) in the normal direction of the contact pair. The relative displacement at contact pair j is illustrated in Figure 4. The initial gap distance É0j* is the shortest distance along the normal vector nj in the direction between the contact and target objects. Thus, if a component of the contact pair is in contact, the initial gap distance is 0. However, if the initial gap distance along the normal vector nj cannot be found on the target object, an extremely large value (e.g. 10âmm or more) is given as the initial spacing, as shown in Figure 5. Figure 4.
The relative normal displacement of a contact pair.
Figure 5.
The initial relative separation of contact and non-contact nodes.

The displacements {u1*} and {u2*} of every contact pair can be calculated from equation (5). The relative separation equation can then be obtained by substituting the displacements {u1*} and {u2*} in equation (6) which is presented as equation (7) (7){s*}=[F*]{R*}+{sp*}+{É0*}

Equation (7) is the relative separation equation of the contact pair in the global coordinate system. The compliance matrix [F*] is calculated from equation (5) by making the external force {P}=0 and applying a pair of unit force to every contact pair. Thus, equation (5) can be rewritten as {ui}=[Ki]-1{Riunit}, where {Riunit} is composed of a vector of unit of force and [F*]=[Ki]-1{Riunit}. The relative displacement vector {sp*} is produced by each contact pair by applying external load {P} and making contact force {R}=0. The relative separation equation is condensed to 4p DOFs.

Since relative separation is calculated in the local coordinate system (nj, tj), the contact force [R*] and the compliance matrix [F*] must be transformed to the local coordinate system. Figure 6 shows the jth contact pair in the local and global coordinate systems. For the contact pair, the angle between direction nj and x-axis is Î±j. The transformation equation from the local coordinate system to the global one can be expressed as equation (8) (8){Rj*}=[Tj]T{Rj}{sj*}=[Tj]T{sj} where {Rj*}={Rxj*Ryj*},âââ{Rj}={RnjRnj},{sj*}={sxj*syj*},âââ{sj}={snjsnj}, and [Tj]T=[cosÎ±j-sinÎ±jsinÎ±jcosÎ±j] Figure 6.
The spatial relationship between the local and global coordinate systems.
Equation (8) can be rewritten as (9){R*}=[T]T{R}{s*}=[T]T{s}} where [T]T=[T1T.0.TjT.0.TnT]

In equation (9), the relative separation {s} and contact force vector {R} of the contact pair are marked in the local coordinate system. The coordinate transformation matrix is denoted as [T]. The normal separation equation in the local coordinate system can be derived from equations (7) and (9) and are presented as (10){s}=[T][F*][T]T{R}+[T]{sp*}+[T]{É0*}

If we assume that [T][F*][T]T=[F], [T]{sp*}={sp}, and [T]{É0*}={É0}, then the relative separation equation in the local coordinate system is presented in equation (11), and [F] is a symmetry matrix (11){s}=[F]{R}+{sp}+{É0}

The contact force is increased when the contact body is gradually rotated toward the target body due to external load {P}. Since the contact problem is a non-linear problem, it is better to apply the external load {P} of the contact body incrementally in order to avoid numerical divergence. The external load is thus divided into several incremental sections and then applied as such to the contact body. The relative separation equation in the incremental form is derived as follows. Assume that the load {Pi-1} plus the incremental load {dpi} is applied on the ith iteration, that contact force {Ri-1} and relative displacement {spi-1} are caused by the loading of {Pi-1}, and that contact force {ri} and relative displacement {dspi} are caused by the effect of load {dPi}. Then, equation (11) can be rewritten as (12){si}=[F]{Ri}+{spi}+{É0}

In equation (12), {Ri}={Ri-1}+{ri}, {Ri-1}=âk=1i-1{rk}, {spi}={spi-1}+{dspi}, and {spi-1}=âk=1i-1{dspk}; therefore, equation (12) can be rewritten as (13){si}=[F]({Ri-1}+{ri})+{spi-1}+{dspi}+{É0}
According to equation (12), {si-1}=[F]{Ri-1}+{spi-1}+{É0}. Equation (14) is given as (14){Éi-1}={si-1}=[F]{Ri-1}+{spi-1}+{É0}
Equation (14) is substituted into equation (13), and the relative separation equation of the contact pair in the incremental form is presented as equation (15) (15){si}=[F]{ri}+{dspi}+{Éi-1}
For the ith iteration, the continuity condition of the contact pair is given as [F]{ri}+{dspi}+{Éi-1}=0
Thus, the continuity equation of the contact pair in the incremental form can be presented as equation (16) (16)[F]{ri}=-{dspi}-{Éi-1}

As shown in Figure 7, the contact gears are simplified as a single tooth contact model. The driving gear is allowed to rotate about O0(x0,y0) and the driven gear is fixed. Therefore, the driving gear is only constrained in the radial direction while the driven gear is completely constrained at the bottom. Figure 7.
Added angular displacement constraint.

As shown in Figure 7, node i1(x1,y1) is attached to the driving gear and O0(x0,y0) is the rotation center of the driving gear. The angle between the xâ²-axis of the local coordinate system of the driving gear and the x-axis of the global coordinate system is Î¸. If the contact and target objects are not in contact in the initial state, then based on the static analysis, a rigid body motion must have occurred. Therefore, it is necessary that an added angular displacement constrained condition {ue} is applied to the driving gear. However, because the nodal freedom of the original compliance matrix is defined in the global coordinate system, the added angular displacement must also be defined in the global coordinate system. After applying the added angular displacement, equation (5) can be rewritten as (17){u}=[K]-1{R}+[K]-1{P}+[Fc*]{ue}
Thus, the relative separation equation in the global coordinate system is expressed as (18){s*}=[F*]{R*}+{sp*}+{É0*}-[Fc*]{ue}

In equation (18), the vector of the relative separation of the contact pair is {s*} and the compliance matrix of the contact force [F*]. Both can be calculated by making {P}=0 and {ue}=0 in equation (17) and then solving it. The vector of the relative displacement {sp*} is produced with external load vector {P} on every contact pair. Similarly, the {sp*} can be calculated by making {R}=0 and {ue}=0 in equation (17) and then solving it.

Each nodal displacement [Fc*]{ue} resulted from {ue} on the driving gears and can be calculated by rigid body motion formulation. The rigid displacement matrix is [Fc*] and can be presented as equation (19) (19)[Fc*]=[â¦-cosÎ¸xi-x0(yi-y0)cosÎ¸xi-x0(xi-x0)â¦]T

In equation (21), Pxi is the x component of the ith loaded section of contact object Î£1 and Pyi the y component of the load of the ith loaded section of contact object Î£1. However, the decision conditions can only be used in the local coordinate system. Therefore, the relative separation equation is transformed from a global coordinate system to a local one. Hence, equation (21) can be rewritten in an incremental form and transformed to the local coordinate system. The relative placing equation can be presented as (22){si}=[F]{Ri}+{spi}+{É0}-[Fc]{uei} where {Ri}={Ri-1}+{ri}, {Ri-1}=âk=1i-1{rk}, {spi}={spi-1}+{dspi}, {spi-1}=âk=1i-1{dspk}, {uei}={uei-1}+{duei}, and {uei-1}=âki-1{duek} and equation (22) can be rewritten as equation (23) (23){si}=[F]({Ri-1}+{ri})+({spi-1}+{dspi})+{É0}âââ-[Fc]({uei-1}+{duei})
The initial normal gap distance in the present iterative calculation is the normal separation resulting from previous iterative calculations {Éi-1}={si-1}=[F]{Ri-1}+{spi-1}+{É0}-[Fc]{uei-1}
Equation (23) can be rewritten as (24){si}=[F]{ri}+{dspi}+{Éi-1}-[Fc]{duei}

Equation (24) is the relative separation equation in incremental form in the local coordinate system. The relative separation equation can be rewritten as the continuity equation and the simultaneous equation with the global equilibrium equation (25)[F]{ri}=-{dspi}-{Éi-1}+[Fc]{duei}[Q]{ri}={Pei}}

In equation (25), contact force {ri} is unknown. When the ith contact pair is in contact, contact forces rni and rti can be solved by equation (25). However, when the ith contact pair is not in contact, we set contact forces rnk and rtk both to 0. Therefore, the compliance matrix [F] is modified and is given as ContactiNon-contactk2i-12i2k-12k[2i-12i2k-12k1â¢â¢â¢â¢1â¢â¢00100001][Right-hand sideâ¢â¢00]

The â¢ means no modifications and the numbers 0 and 1 indicate the filled-in number. Thus, contact force {ri} is solved by equation (25) when the ith contact pair is in contact, while separation {si} is solved by equation (24) when the ith contact pair is in contact. If the solved contact force {ri} at the contact pair is negative, then the ith contact pair is changed to a non-contact status; if the solved separation {si} is negative at the non-contact pair, then the ith contact pair is changed to a contact status. The compliance matrix [F] in equation (25) should be changed according to the new contact status. The ith iteration is completed when all solved {ri} and {si} meet the contact status decision condition presented in Table 1. Then, contact force {R} is substituted in equation (5) to calculate all the displacements. The initial contact status of the contact pair is given with the aid of the rigid body TCA. With TCA, we can find the initial normal gap distance with zero loading. The contact pair with an initial normal gap distance less than 6âÂµm is assumed to be in contact for the first iteration.

Finally, results {R} and {ue} which meet the contact condition can be obtained by solving equations (24) and (25). Furthermore, {R} and {ue} are substituted into equation (17), and then, all the nodal displacements of the elastic objects can be obtained by solving equation (17).

sec.title: Solving the spur gear contact problem by the HFEM with TCA
sec.p: In order to save computation time and simplify the computation process of the HFEM, we use the pro-processing function of the ANSYS program to build the FEMs of the gear contact pairs. The entire stiffness matrix can be exported from ANSYS for calculating the HFEM. In ANSYS, the entire stiffness matrices are exported by three methods: HBMAT, user-defined function (UDF), and SE.

UDF needs a preprocessing program to operate ANSYS in batch mode and requires extra preparation for the programs. Thus, this study adopted SE and HBMAT to export the entire stiffness matrix. SE is an analytic method of the so-called substructuring in ANSYS. Substructuring is a procedure that condenses a group of finite elements into a SE. This reduces the computation time and the dimensions of the entire stiffness matrix and allows the solution of very large problems. The physical meaning of condensation refers to the fact that some nodes of the FEM model have no connection with the other elements. That is, these nodes are irrelevant to the other elements. Hence, these nodes are referred to as inner nodes and the others connective nodes. Since the inner nodes have no relationship with the other elements, we erase them before forming the entire stiffness matrix. So, the displacement of the inner nodes can be replaced by that of the connective ones. This condensation method is employed in this article.

The process of iterative calculations is demonstrated in Figure 8. Since the stiffness matrix in this study is calculated by ANSYS, the FEM of the gear pair is built first. Then, the entire stiffness matrix is condensed using SE, which makes all the nodes of the entire stiffness matrix be near the contact boundary and reduces the dimensions of the entire stiffness matrix. Then, the condensed stiffness matrix can be exported in order to calculate the HFEM by HBMAT. The FEM and the boundary conditions in ANSYS are shown in Figure 9. On top is the driven gear whose bottom (near the axis) is fully constrained. At the bottom is the driving gear which is only constrained in the normal and axial directions. Then, the nodal force is applied to the bottom of the driving gear in the tangent direction with a force equivalent to the torque. Figure 8.
Flowchart: calculation using HFEM.
HFEM: hybrid finite element method.
Figure 9.
The FEM model and boundary conditions of the gears.
FEM: finite element method.

The total DOFs of the FEM for a 3-D tooth is increased in cubic order; however, the total DOFs of the HFEM model is increased in second order since all DOFs are condensed to the contacting surfaces. This means that the calculation time for the 3-D HFEM is better than the 2-D contact problem compared to the FEM.

The applied torque is divided into several incremental sections for the incremental iterative analysis and then the nodal contact force {ri} and the added displacement {duei} are solved by equation (25) with contact status decision condition. Next, the results of the nodal contact force and the added displacement are substituted into the relative separation equation (24) and the contact status is checked again. As a result, the sum of the nodal contact forces and the added displacement in every iterative calculation are computed to calculate the displacement of all the nodes using equation (5) when the incremental value of the torque reaches the initial value. Based on the result, the stress distribution of the FEM can then be obtained.

sec.title: Numerical examples and discussions
sec.p: In this article, we will compare the numerical result of HFEM to that of ANSYS in order to verify our proposed methodology. The Solid45 element with eight nodes is chosen for the meshing tooth model. The Youngâs modulus of the element is 206,000âMPa and the Poisson ratio 0.3. The boundary condition is shown in Figure 9. Then, the nodal force is applied to the bottom of the driving gear in a tangent direction. The resultant torque of the nodal force is equivalent to the applied torque.

sec.title: Comparing the differences in computational time for FEM and HFEM
sec.p:
First, we build a 2-D FEM model of the spur gear of different divided sections, numbers (21, 42, 60, 81, and 101) on the involute section (contact area) of the spur gear with different torque loadings (1000, 2000, 3000, 4000, 5000, 6000, 7000, and 8000âN-mm). The results are shown in Figures 10 and 11, and indicate that the computational time of HFEM is shorter than that of ANSYS under the different torque loadings and divided sections. The torque is 8000âN-mm and the divided section numbers 21, 42, 60, 81, and 101. The comparison of the computational time between ANSYS and HFEM is shown in Figure 12. The other example, the time comparison when the divided section number is 101 and the torque loadings 1000, 2000, 3000, 4000, 5000, 6000, 7000, and 8000âN-mm, is shown in Figure 13. The name of the curve in both Figures 12 and 13 is on the right hand side. It is obvious that the computational time of HFEM is less than that of ANSYS. Figure 10.
The computation time under different torque loadings in ANSYS.
Figure 11.
The computation time under different torque loadings in HFEM.
HFEM: hybrid finite element method.
Figure 12.
The difference in computation time when the torque is 8000âN-mm.
Figure 13.
The difference in computation time for section number 101.

sec.title: Result of the static contact analysis of the spur gear
sec.p:
The numerical result of ANSYS is shown in Figure 14. The torque loading is 30,000âN-mm and the von Mises maximal stress of the driving gears 377.367âMPa. The contact line is a straight line. For verifying the accuracy of HFEM, we take the nodes attached to the contact line. The comparison of the analytical results using HFEM and ANSYS is presented in Table 2. It is clear that the gap value of the contact node is 0âmm, but there is some gap value in the result using HFEM and all these gap values are less than 1âÂµm. The deviation of the nodal contact force is shown in the right column. The largest deviation is about 12.8354% on node 144. The numbering order of the node from top to bottom in Table 2 is shown in Figure 14 as the direction of the red line and also that of the contact line of the gear tooth. Figure 14.
Result of the contact analysis of a cylindrical spur gear using ANSYS.

2665 0.0000 59.2830 â0.0000245043 59.2351 0.0810
2666 0.0000 59.3907 â0.0000232407 59.2144 0.2976
2667 0.0000 59.5265 â0.0000233936 59.1820 0.5822
2668 0.0000 59.6752 â0.0000218491 59.2036 0.7965
2669 0.0000 59.8144 â0.0000233126 59.0629 1.2724
2670 0.0000 59.8683 â0.0000214744 59.0108 1.4530
2671 0.0000 59.6880 â0.0000100205 57.7507 3.3546
2672 0.0000 58.2706 â0.0000738242 61.0667 4.5787
144 0.0000 26.8902 0.0001261970 30.8499 12.8354
HFEM: hybrid finite element method.

For the analytical result of the 3-D model, the computational time of HFEM is longer than that of ANSYS. We therefore use the result of the TCA to reduce the possible contact area. As shown in Figure 15, the original shrunken contact area indicates the entire surface of the gear tooth, the so-called efficacious contact zone in this study. However, we use the result of the TCA to find the contact zone with a 6âÂµm normal gap distance as the instantaneous contact zone and remodel the compliance matrix. A torque loading of 30,000âN-mm is applied in the FEM gear model of gear. The numerical results are presented in Table 3. The computational time using ANSYS is 167âs. For the efficacious and instantaneous contact zones, the computational time using HFEM is 1235âs and 48âs, respectively. Although the time is decreased by 96%, the deviation is increased in comparison to the results from ANSYS. The analysis results of the efficacious and instantaneous contact zone by both HFEM and ANSYS are shown in Figure 16. Figure 15.
Diagram of the efficacious and instantaneous contact zones.
Figure 16.
Trend chart of the nodal contact force.

144 26.8902 30.8499 12.8354 30.4657 11.7361
HFEM: hybrid finite element method.

sec.title: Contact analysis of the cylindrical crown gear: Statistics
sec.p:
Tooth surface modification is usually applied to the gear to compensate for the deformation due to force, manufacturing error, and interference by the meshing gear, to reduce noise and to extend the life of the gears. Crowning is done by removing a small amount of the tooth material and making the tooth surface slightly convex, as shown in Figure 17. The amount of modification Î is suggested to be between 0.013 and 0.035âmm. In this article, the size of the lengthwise crowning is 0.01âmm and the amount of profile modification 0.005âmm. The modified curve is the normal quadratic curve, as shown by the blue line in Figure 18, and r is the radius of the curvature. Figure 17.
Lengthwise crowning.
Figure 18.
Modified curve: quadratic curve.

The analytical result of the crowned gear using ANSYS is shown in Figure 19. The maximum von Mises stress is 367.834âMPa and the contact line in an ellipse-like shape. The numerical results from using HFEM and ANSYS are compared in Table 4 and Figure 20 along the instantaneous contact line. They indicate that the results of these two methods are consistent with each other. However, the compliance matrix of the HFEM is adopted from the standard tooth profile while the stiffness matrix of ANSYS needs to be recalculated. Figure 19.
Result of the contact analysis of a crowned tooth using ANSYS.
Figure 20.
Trend chart of the nodal contact force of a crowned tooth. Table 4.
Comparing the result of crowning a tooth using HFEM vs ANSYS.
Node number ANSYS HFEM
Nodal contact force (N) Nodal contact force (N) Deviation of the contact force (%)
12,797 30.61 24.37 20.37
12,763 56.61 54.34 4.00
11,488 71.54 77.23 7.95
11,296 76.39 81.40 6.56
11,295 71.54 76.51 6.94
11,655 56.61 55.28 2.34
11,950 30.60 24.78 19.02
HFEM: hybrid finite element method.

As shown in Table 2, the overall average deviation of the normal direction of the contact node is 2.5%, and only the deviation of the nodes at the edges is increased to 12%. This significant error of the nodal contact force at the edges is caused by the effect of stress concentration when the edge contact occurs. The other nodal error of the tooth surface is less than 2.5% and therefore the accuracy of HFEM is dependable. Although it saves time to condense the entire stiffness matrix when calculating the contact problem, the amount of error increases substantially, as presented in Table 3.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
In this study, the HFEM was applied to analyze the tooth contact stress of a gear pair.
The contact force was iteratively solved by condensed compliance matrix and normal gap distance with a DOF in the possible contact region. The computation time was reduced because the size of the condensed compliance matrix was less than the total stiffness matrix.
The initial normal gap distance calculated by the rigid body TCA with a 6âÂµm threshold value was a good estimation of the contact status.
The contact stress of the meshing gears calculated by HFEM was consistent with the ANSYS result.
The compliance matrices for the modified tooth profile were almost the same. This allows us to study the contact stress for different tooth surface crownings without having to recalculate the compliance matrix. We only need to add the amount of surface modification to the initial normal gap distance and then recalculate the contact force.
Thus, the HFEM can be used to solve the analytic contact problem of the gear pair and effectively improve the computational time required.
